trans-unit.source: Getting started with Azure Blob storage and Visual Studio connected services
trans-unit.target: Getting started with Azure Blob storage and Visual Studio connected services

trans-unit.source: How to get started using Azure Blob storage in a Visual Studio ASP.NET 5 project
trans-unit.target: How to get started using Azure Blob storage in a Visual Studio ASP.NET 5 project

trans-unit.source: This article describes how get started using Azure Blob storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET 5 project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how get started using Azure Blob storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET 5 project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: A single blob can be any size.
trans-unit.target: A single blob can be any size.

trans-unit.source: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.
trans-unit.target: Blobs can be things like images, audio and video files, raw data, and document files.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to get started with blob storage after you create an Azure storage account by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog in an ASP.NET 5 project.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to get started with blob storage after you create an Azure storage account by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog in an ASP.NET 5 project.

trans-unit.source: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.
trans-unit.target: Just as files live in folders, storage blobs live in containers.

trans-unit.source: After you have created a storage, you create one or more containers in the storage.
trans-unit.target: After you have created a storage, you create one or more containers in the storage.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a storage called “Scrapbook,” you can create containers in the storage called “images” to store pictures and another called “audio” to store audio files.

trans-unit.source: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.
trans-unit.target: After you create the containers, you can upload individual blob files to them.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title>How to use blob storage from .NET</title> for more information on programmatically manipulating blobs.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title>How to use blob storage from .NET</title> for more information on programmatically manipulating blobs.

trans-unit.source: To programmatically access blobs in ASP.NET 5 projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.
trans-unit.target: To programmatically access blobs in ASP.NET 5 projects, you need to add the following items, if they're not already present.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you want to programmatically access Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code namespace declarations to the top of any C# file in which you want to programmatically access Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudStorageAccountobject that represents your storage account information.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudStorageAccountobject that represents your storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.

trans-unit.source: NOTE: Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: Use a CloudBlobClient object to get a CloudBlobContainer reference to an existing container in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Use a CloudBlobClient object to get a CloudBlobContainer reference to an existing container in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the CloudBlobClient to create a container in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the CloudBlobClient to create a container in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: All you need to do is to add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync as in the following code:
trans-unit.target: All you need to do is to add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync as in the following code:

trans-unit.source: NOTE: The APIs that perform calls to Azure storage in ASP.NET 5 are asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: The APIs that perform calls to Azure storage in ASP.NET 5 are asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Asynchronous programming with Async and Await</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Asynchronous programming with Async and Await</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: The code below assumes async programming methods are being used.
trans-unit.target: The code below assumes async programming methods are being used.

trans-unit.source: To make the files within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public by using the following code.
trans-unit.target: To make the files within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public by using the following code.

trans-unit.source: To upload a blob file into a container, get a container reference and use it to get a blob reference.
trans-unit.target: To upload a blob file into a container, get a container reference and use it to get a blob reference.

trans-unit.source: After you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the UploadFromStreamAsync method.
trans-unit.target: After you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the UploadFromStreamAsync method.

trans-unit.source: This operation creates the blob if it’s not already there, or overwrites it if it does exist.
trans-unit.target: This operation creates the blob if it’s not already there, or overwrites it if it does exist.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.

trans-unit.source: You can then call the container's ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.
trans-unit.target: You can then call the container's ListBlobsSegmentedAsync method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.

trans-unit.source: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned IListBlobItem, you must cast it to a CloudBlockBlob, CloudPageBlob, or CloudBlobDirectory object.
trans-unit.target: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned IListBlobItem, you must cast it to a CloudBlockBlob, CloudPageBlob, or CloudBlobDirectory object.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t know the blob type, you can use a type check to determine which to cast it to.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t know the blob type, you can use a type check to determine which to cast it to.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in a container.
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in a container.

trans-unit.source: There are others ways to list the contents of a blob container.
trans-unit.target: There are others ways to list the contents of a blob container.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: TTo download a blob, first get a reference to the blob, and then call the DownloadToStreamAsync method.
trans-unit.target: TTo download a blob, first get a reference to the blob, and then call the DownloadToStreamAsync method.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the DownloadToStreamAsync method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then save as a local file.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the DownloadToStreamAsync method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then save as a local file.

trans-unit.source: There are other ways to save blobs as files.
trans-unit.target: There are other ways to save blobs as files.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to use blob storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, first get a reference to the blob, and then call the DeleteAsync method on it.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, first get a reference to the blob, and then call the DeleteAsync method on it.
